ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The CalARP Program developed for this facility is designed to prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating and implementing our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in design, construction, start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the CalARP Program regulation.  This comprehensive program has been developed to enable all those who may be affected to be able to identify and understand the hazards posed by the ammonia refrigeration system and the sulfur dioxide process.



Employees are provided with hazard awareness training and participate in the implementation of the Program.  This Program document, as well as the other documents and reports that are created pursuant to this Program, are made accessible to our employees and to other affected persons in accordance with applicable requirements and the provisions of the CalARP Program.



Emergency planning and response measures have been developed and implemented for proper and safe evacuation and notifications to outside emergency responders.  These measures reflect the established policies of this facility for ensuring the health and safety of all employees and those who may be on site or in the area in the event of an accidental release of ammonia or sulfur dioxide.



This CalARP Program is regularly reviewed and updated as required, and whenever necessary to reflect new or modified tasks and procedures.  Facility personnel ensure that safety and environmental policies are implemented at this facility by conducting periodic compliance inspections.



This CalARP Program includes additional elements as required for compliance with the federal EPA Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements and the OSHA PSM Standard.  The use of the term "CalARP Program" throughout the program documents implies inclusion of all applicable accidental

release prevention and process safety management requirements.



 

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



This facility operates one (1) anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system and one (1) sulfur dioxide process.



Facility Description



Bronco Wine Company, produces wines at its Stanislaus County facility in Ceres, California.

 

The plant entrance is located along Bystrum Road and the facility is bordered by E. Keyes Road to the north, Pike Road on the east, and E. Taylor on the south.  The entrance lies approximately 2-? miles east of S. Carpenter Road and about 3.2 miles directly northeast of State Highway.  The small town of Keyes is located east of the facility along Highway 99.  The area is largely agricultural with a few residences in the area.



The facility maintains approximately 380 full time employees on site.  The plant operates three (3) shifts five (5) days a week throughout the year, except during the grape harvest season, when operation extends to seven (7) days a week and additional employees are hired for the season.  



The plant is comprised of offices, production and laboratory buildings, loading docks, warehouses, parking, tank farms, and wastewater ponds.  The facility is fenced along the entire perimeter and there is a security guard shack at the entrance.



The Emergency Evacuation Assembly Areas are located as required for potential evacuations.  Employees are trained and drill for alarm responses and evacuations annually.



Process Description - Ammonia Refrigeration



The refrigeration system uses anhydrous ammonia as the heat transfer fluid.  The ammonia refrigeration process is a closed-loop, single-stage, mechanical refrigeration system, with little or no need for operator involvement.  The system is automatically controlled by a programmable logic controller, which minimizes the potential for human error.



Facility maintenance mechanics regularly monitor process parameters, including pressure, temperatu

re, and vessel levels for proper operation.  Abnormal conditions may be corrected by mechanics when trained for the task and when safe to do so but are typically referred to the refrigeration contractor technician.  A qualified ammonia refrigeration company provides service, design, and most regular preventive maintenance for the system.



Most of the equipment is located outside, except for two chiller packages, which are located in the Mezzanine above the Barrel Room.  Jacketed wine tanks, chillers, compressors, condensers, and receivers are located throughout the site.



System components are connected with steel piping approved for ammonia refrigeration service and the system includes numerous safety devices, detection systems, alarms, and control valves.  Physical protective measures and emergency shower and eyewash stations are located as required to improve safety.  Oil pots are provided at various pressure vessels for periodically draining accumulated refrigerant oil safely.



Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID) provide a graphical description of the system.  Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) describe the modes of operation, safety and health considerations, operating limits, and the safety systems and their functions.  The ammonia refrigeration system is audited regularly for mechanical integrity and complies with industry standards and the applicable codes and regulations.



The ammonia refrigeration system at Bronco Wine Company is used for controlling fermentation, chilling wine (referred to as "cold stabilization") and chilling grape juice.  The system is also used to produce cold glycol which is used for temperature controlled warehouse storage.  The system contains approximately 275,000 lbs. of ammonia.



Juice and wine are stored in tanks.  The typical tank is constructed of epoxy coated stainless steel and insulated with high density foam insulation.  A small number of tanks have ammonia jackets installed.  The juice or wine st

ored in tanks without jackets is pumped to a shell and tube heat exchanger for temperature control.



The refrigeration cycle operates on the principle of the latent heat of vaporization and the transfer/absorption of heat that occurs as a result.  The compressors provide high-temperature, high-pressure vapor as ammonia vapor is compressed.  Next, the evaporative condensers remove the heat of compression generated when the ammonia vapor is compressed.



The result of evaporative condensing is a high-pressure liquid, which drains to the receiver and is made available for cooling via control valves to other parts of the system.  As cooling is required in chillers or wine tank jackets, the liquid is metered and pumped from the suction accumulators.  As the liquid ammonia passes through the cooling coils or chillers, it absorbs heat from the wine and subsequently expands and vaporizes as the pressure of the ammonia drops.



The resulting liquid/vapor mixture is returned from the chillers to the accumulators, where the liquid and vapor are separated to protect the compressors from liquid slugging.  Ammonia vapor is returned to the compressors to repeat the cycle and accumulated liquid ammonia at the bottom of the vessel supplies the pumps.  



Emergency switches are located in the Compressor Areas for emergency shutdown.  



The Primary System Components include:



EQUIPMENT    QUANTITY

Reciprocating Compressors w/ separate oil separators    2

Screw Compressors w/ integral oil separators    7

Evaporative Condensers    11

High-Pressure Receivers    6

Suction Accumulators    6

Liquid Transfer Units    5

Chillers (Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers)    48

Ammonia Pumps    7

Oil Pots    3

Jacketed Wine Tanks    18



 

Process Description - Sulfur Dioxide Process



Sulfur dioxide gas is added to wines and juices to prevent unwanted microbial activity.  Sulfur dioxide is also used to protect the headspace (air space at the top of a vessel) of storage tanks and barrels.



Sulfur dioxide is transf

erred from one-ton cylinders to 6 lb., 25 lb., and 100 lb. portable cylinders.  The portable cylinders are transported to the point of use for injection into fruit juice, pulp and/or skins to inhibit unwanted microbial activity.



No chemical reactions or special process temperatures need to be maintained.  The process involves the simple transfer from a larger vessel to a smaller one.  Plant nitrogen is connected and opened to the vapor valve of the one-ton cylinder to assist in the transfer of liquid sulfur dioxide.  The amount (pounds) loaded into the canister is monitored by the operator observing the liquid level sight glass on the canister.



The operation is conducted outdoors.  A bleed line is available during portable tank filling.  A second bleed line is also available to purge residual sulfur dioxide within the transfer lines before hoses are disconnected.  These bleed lines are connected to a scrubber system which is continuously fed water.  Since sulfur dioxide is soluble in the water (forming sulfurous acid), no emissions are produced.  Clean water passes through the scrubber continuously, thus, the water discharged to drain doesn't become over saturated with sulfur dioxide and a highly corrosive acid is not produced.



Sulfur dioxide from a one-ton cylinder is injected into the must line containing juice to inhibit fermentation.  The feed rate is controlled by a mass flow meter and metering pump.  Sulfur dioxide is soluble in water and juice, so no emissions are produced.  The quantity of sulfur dioxide added is determined by the wine maker.  The metering pump is interlocked with the must pump such that sulfur dioxide is only added when the must pump is on.



Sulfur dioxide gas is also used to prevent the growth of harmful bacteria in full and empty barrels in the Barrel Room.  Sulfur dioxide is injected from a 6 lb. dispenser into the head space of barrels before and after they are filled with wine for aging.

 

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PR

EVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The release prevention steps listed in the CalARP Program manual (Chapter 7 (Release Prevention Program)) include the critical elements for preventing accidental releases.  These steps include all elements as required for Program 3 release prevention.  Specifically, the elements of the release prevention Program 3 require and include:



1.    Process Safety Information

2.    Process Hazard Analysis

3.    Operating Procedures

4.    Training

5.    Mechanical Integrity

6.    Management of Change

7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review

8.    Compliance Audits

9.    Incident Investigation

10.    Employee Participation

11.    Hot Work Permit

12.    Contractors



This facility involves employees in the program, qualifies contractors before hire, conducts pre-startup safety and work assessments, implements hot work procedures and permitting, and manages changes in the processes with comprehensive procedures and documentation.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



On August 13, 2016, a release occurred which is subject to the California Accidental Release Prevention Program and federal EPA Accidental Release Prevention Program five-year accident history reporting requirements.  The contributing factor was a pipe support bracket failure, which allowed pipe movement and gasket failure.  Replacement and/or additional pipe supports have been installed on the chillers or are scheduled for installation to preclude similar incidents in the future.  The failed flange gasket at the chiller was replaced, also.  Applied Process Cooling Corporation (APCCO) was contracted to conduct a safety assessment of the facility.  See "2016 CUPA-APCCO Safety Evaluation Action Plan" for mitigation plan and efforts.



 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Bronco Wine Company maintains an Emergency Planning & Response Program as described in the Emergency Action Plan.  As a facility that will respond to uncontrolled releases, the emergency response measures primarily include 1.the s

afe evacuation of all personnel and notification to outside emergency responders.  Incidental releases that do not pose an imminent safety hazard may be abated by employees or contractor who are trained to provide such a response, are wearing the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), and are authorized by Bronco Wine Company to perform such activities.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



1.  Modify maintenance program activities and documentation.

2.  Review impact protection for system equipment.

3.  Review safe work practices.

4.  Training program modifications.

5.  Revise ammonia system operating procedures.

6.  Improve labeling of equipment and piping.

7.  Emergency response plan modifications.

8.  Evaluate several equipment changes.

9.  Review ammonia system control drawings for currency.

10. Develop accurate and complete P&IDs for the sulfur dioxide system.

11. Develop accurate and complete operating procedures for the sulfur dioxide system.
